During the first century os our era few men at Rome acquired or retained power in the state without having denounced disaffection to the person of the emperor. Such denunciations became necessary as a pledge of loyalty astera man had-risen, they were convenient while a man was rising: under the conditions ol the Roman state it was useful toan ambitious politician to be loved‚ it was essential to be seared: by'obliging one man he commonly disobliged another; by mining· one man he terrorised all. Nor does Tacitus leave an attentive reader under the impression that these denunciations were exactly frivolous. The Roman criminal law was terribly clastic: Law is never precise except when it is interpreted by ¹courts with a continuous tradition, and when offences are punished with sufficient certainty to remove the motive for capricious and exemplary severity. The sweeping ferocity ol Roman legislation under the late Republic and the early Empire was natural to inexperienced reformers who could not count upon their zeal being seconded by the steady activity ol the courts. Almost as many were condemned under the empire for offences against morality and religion as lor attempts against the security or the dignity ol the emperor. To take one instance out ol many, there is not really any better reason for doubting that Barea and his daughter had been guilty of a capital crime than sor supposing they deserved to be put to death.
